articles.headline: On Defensive, BP Readies Dome to Contain Spill
articles.snippet: Crews were building a containment dome, a 4-story, 70-ton structure that the company plans to lower into place over one of the three leaks to catch the escaping oil.
articles.abstract: Crews were building a containment dome, a 4-story, 70-ton structure that the company plans to lower into place over one of the three leaks to catch the escaping oil.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Ian Urbina, Justin Gillis and Clifford Krauss.
articles.byline: By Ian Urbina, Justin Gillis and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Russian Orphanage Offers Love, but Not Families
articles.snippet: The case of an adopted boy who was sent back by a family in the U.S. has focused attention on a troubled system.
articles.abstract: The case of an adopted boy who was sent back by a family in the U.S. has focused attention on a troubled system.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — There is nothing dreary about Orphanage No. 11. It has rooms filled with enough dolls and trains and stuffed animals to make any child giggly. It has speech therapists and round-the-clock nurses and cooks who delight in covertly slipping a treat into a tiny hand. It has the feel of a place where love abounds.

articles.headline: Farmers Cope With Roundup-Resistant Weeds
articles.snippet: Heavy use of the weedkiller Roundup has led to the rapid growth of herbicide-resistant weeds that could lead to higher food prices and more pollution.
articles.abstract: Heavy use of the weedkiller Roundup has led to the rapid growth of herbicide-resistant weeds that could lead to higher food prices and more pollution.
articles.lead_paragraph: DYERSBURG, Tenn. — For 15 years, Eddie Anderson, a farmer, has been a strict adherent of no-till agriculture, an environmentally friendly technique that all but eliminates plowing to curb erosion and the harmful runoff of fertilizers and pesticides.
articles.byline: By William Neuman and Andrew Pollack

articles.headline: For Obama, a Nonstop Juggling Act
articles.snippet: President Obama seeks to balance his regard for the free market and the job-creating potential of big business against the need to respond to voters convinced that corporate America has only its own interests at heart.
articles.abstract: President Obama seeks to balance his regard for the free market and the job-creating potential of big business against the need to respond to voters convinced that corporate America has only its own interests at heart.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s spokesman promised for a second day on Monday that the administration would “keep our boot on the throat of BP” to get the company to resolve the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Yet, hours later, the president was hosting dinner at the White House with executives of the Business Council. Among the companies represented by the corporate club: BP.

articles.headline: From Buffett, Thought-Out Support for Goldman
articles.snippet: Warren Buffett is one prominent person who has publicly supported Goldman Sachs, and he may have a point.
articles.abstract: Warren Buffett is one prominent person who has publicly supported Goldman Sachs, and he may have a point.

articles.headline: Spain Seen as Moving Slowly on Financial Reforms
articles.snippet: Analysts say the Spanish government’s lack of progress on banking issues underscores its shortcomings in addressing broader problems like crushing deficits.
articles.abstract: Analysts say the Spanish government’s lack of progress on banking issues underscores its shortcomings in addressing broader problems like crushing deficits.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — A planned merger has stalled between two weak savings banks in Galicia, in northwestern Spain, illustrating the reluctance of the Spanish government to take a firmer hand to its financial problems.

articles.headline: After Day of Calm, Anxiety Returns to Europe’s Markets
articles.snippet: Markets fell sharply on renewed concerns about the sovereign debt problems in Europe.
articles.abstract: Markets fell sharply on renewed concerns about the sovereign debt problems in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: Europe’s nervous markets were calmed, at last, on Monday after the European Union and the International Monetary Fund broke their logjam and approved a long-delayed financial rescue package for Greece. But then Tuesday came, and that poise vanished.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Christine Hauser
